335.name: 1st (Incomes across the Distribution Database (2016))
335.description: Household disposable income by income decile for the entire population. Indexed to the first year for which data is available for each country.
335.timespan: Data coverage differs by country – for some countries data goes back to 1978 while coverage is shorter for some other countries. Data is currently available until 2013.
335.datasetName: Incomes across the Distribution Database (authored by Nolan, Thewissen, Roser; based on LIS) indexed to the first year (2016)
335.s_name: Incomes across the Distribution Database (authored by Nolan, Thewissen, Roser; based on LIS) indexed to the first year (2016)

source.name: Incomes across the Distribution Database (authored by Nolan, Thewissen, Roser; based on LIS) indexed to the first year (2016)
source.dataPublisherSource: Based on microdata from the Luxembourg Income Study Database
source.link: The entire database was published by Brian Nolan, Stefan Thewissen here https://ourworldindata.org/incomes-across-the-distribution/
source.additionalInfo: The decile cut-offs  are calculated on the basis of disposable household income. The measure of disposable household income employed in the Luxembourg Income Study is paid employment and self-employment income, capital income, transfer income, which includes social security transfers (work-related insurance transfers, universal benefits, and assistance benefits) and private transfers, minus income taxes and social security contributions. This follows the definitions of the Canberra Group.
